verses.text: I will exalt you, O LORD, for you have lifted me up and have not let my enemies rejoice over me.
verses.comment: Lifting up often signifies resurrection or restoration, a theme echoed in New Testament passages about Christ (cf. John 12:32). The psalmist's trust in being raised anticipates Christian hope in redemption.

verses.text: O LORD my God, I cried to you for help, and you healed me.
verses.comment: Divine healing points to both physical and spiritual restoration. In the Gospel healings, Jesus demonstrates his authority to heal body and soul, confirming his divinity (see Mark 2:9-12).

verses.text: O LORD, you brought up my soul from Sheol; you restored me to life from among those going down to the pit.
verses.comment: Reference to 'Sheol' and restoration foreshadows the resurrection. Peter links Psalm 16:10 to Christ’s resurrection in Acts 2:27. The psalmist’s experience serves as a sign for God's power over death.

verses.text: Sing praise to the LORD, you his faithful ones, and give thanks to his holy name.
verses.comment: The call to communal worship presumes the need for assembly and unity among the faithful, a principle the early Church (Acts 2:46-47) held as essential for Christian practice.

verses.text: For his anger is only for a moment, but his favor is for life. Weeping may stay for the night, but rejoicing comes in the morning.
verses.comment: The contrast between temporary sorrow and lasting joy speaks of hope beyond suffering. Early Christians saw this as reflective of Christ's Passion and Resurrection—night turning to dawn for his people.

verses.text: As for me, in my prosperity I said, 'I will never be shaken.'
verses.comment: Trusting in one's own security is common, but the psalmist’s experience reminds believers true stability comes from God alone, inviting humility and reliance on God in all stages of life.

verses.text: O LORD, by your favor you established me as a strong mountain; but when you hid your face, I was terrified.
verses.comment: The 'hiding of God's face' echoes the sense of distance felt in spiritual dryness, which God sometimes allows to bring about deeper growth and conversion. God's favor is foundational for perseverance.

verses.text: To you, O LORD, I cried, and to the Lord I made my supplication:
verses.comment: Supplication is a form of humble, persistent prayer. The Psalmist's turning to God mirrors Christ’s prayer in Gethsemane (Luke 22:42), emphasizing the pattern of appeal in faithful suffering.

verses.text: 'What profit is there in my death, if I go down to the pit? Will the dust praise you? Will it declare your faithfulness?'
verses.comment: Ancient Hebrews saw Sheol as a place of silence, yet Christ transforms this by conquering death and calling believers to eternal praise (cf. Revelation 5:9).

verses.text: Hear, O LORD, and be gracious to me! O LORD, be my helper!
verses.comment: Grace is sought in prayer; in the New Testament, God's grace is fully revealed and accessible through the ministry of Christ (Hebrews 4:16), especially as believers participate in divine life.

verses.text: You have turned my mourning into dancing; you have taken off my sackcloth and clothed me with gladness,
verses.comment: God’s ability to transform sorrow into joy prefigures the Christian passage from death to life. This is spiritually realized as believers share in Christ’s victory and are clothed with joy.

verses.text: so that my glory may sing your praise and not be silent. O LORD my God, I will give you thanks forever.
verses.comment: Eternal praise comes as the proper response to God's redemption. The enduring praise of God’s people continues into eternity (cf. Revelation 19:5). This connects with the enduring worship that is central to Christian identity.
